body:
Hi @dchristle @coufon 
When are we expecting it to be available with standard iceberg-spark-runtime?
We have some use cases for it to be used with the Iceberg Kafka Connector. I am not able to fetch this artifact from maven.

Please guide me. Thanks.
@RussellSpitzer @singhpk234, could you take another look? I fixed the test.
Thanks, @RussellSpitzer @singhpk234!

@aokolnychyi

I got the same issue on calling `rewrite_manifests()` to the table with S3 bucket(via `S3FileIo`) storage and Glue catalog backend.

I tested this procedure on the EMR `v6.7` (packaged with Spark version `3.2.1` and Iceberg version `0.13.1-amzn-0`)

This table is being ingested from realtime stream (append-only fashion), and the metadata-management procedures are sequentially called on hourly batch, with the order below.

`rewrite_data_files` -> `expire_snapshots` -> `rewrite_manifests` -> `remove_orphan_files`

According to the thread on your PR #4652, this update was back-ported to Spark `v3.2`. (Is it not the perfect defender for this issue..yet..?) or... AWS own custom version is not updated with those back-ported commits..?)

How can I prevent this issue..?

I actually have some concerns about this change, which I outlined in [this](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1M4L6o-qnGRwGhbhkW8BnravoTwvCrJV8VvzVQDRJO5I) doc.
I have an alternative implementation in PR #8755 that I want to consider before this change is released.

@aokolnychyi 

I got the issue only related to metadata files, on `rewrite_manifests()` procedure call, as I said on the other issue.

https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/4161#issuecomment-1793318058

But, if this issue can be raised on the data file itself, as @jotarada said.. is it not safe to call `delete_orphan_files` periodically, when there is no backup storage to backfill data..?

I got the same issue..

https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/4161#issuecomment-1793318058
Superseded by #8986.
Or have a feature flag (default false) to control this?

#8805 was merged so I'll close this. I should also note that @aokolnychyi raised some concerns about this approach instead of a more comprehensive fix. This is probably a good start if we don't add further caching.
@yabola @nastra PTAL, thanks!

This error occurs only in Athena, while running a query on the table using Spark works fine. According to the [Amazon EMR documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/emr/latest/ReleaseGuide/emr-iceberg.html), Apache Iceberg is an open table format for large data sets in Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3). It provides fast query performance over large tables, atomic commits, concurrent writes, and SQL-compatible table evolution. Starting with Amazon EMR 6.5.0, you can use Apache Spark 3 on Amazon EMR clusters with the Iceberg table format.

We enabled S3 versioning on the bucket and can see a file name being used 2 times by 2 distincts micro-batches. So it is not a case of task retry inside Spark. 

This issue leads to data loss as the original file is replaced and metadata corruption as there is a reference to a file that does not exists anymore.

Hi @chenwyi2 @pvary , thanks for the clarifications. Yeah we changed our snapshot expire routine to keep the last snapshot created by Flink. If this is a limitation by design, I guess it's better to mention this in the doc.

Hello everyone,

After several attempts, I managed to solve the mergeSchema issue I was facing. The solution was to apply the following configuration. I suspect that the check-ordering is set to true by default, which can cause errors when columns are out of order. This happens even when following the documentation's instructions. Without applying the configuration below, I was receiving the 'column is out of order' error.

`--conf spark.sql.iceberg.check-ordering=false`

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has been open for 180 days with no activity. It will be closed in next 14 days if no further activity occurs. body:
Spark:3.3
Iceberg:13.0
Encountering the same problem

I also have this problem. I use the iceberg table of hive Catalog, and the operation is rewrite_data_file-> rewrite_manifest-> expire_snapshot, but the problem of â€œManifest is missing..." occasionally occurs in the operation of rewrite_manifest. How do you solve the problem
Sure, I'll open a PR for it

@dragon-feng can you please provide the full stack trace and your catalog configuration? Without this it's quite difficult to tell what went wrong. Also please share the exact command you're executing when the error happens.
primary key in flink is identifier fields in iceberg
Thank you @FabricioZGalvani !! It worked!!

@nk1506: I have a few concerns here:

1. `listAllTables` - This configuration has been explicitly created to prevent reading all of the actual table data for the given database (namespace). If we keep this, then we should be sure that we do not need specific table data (even by batches). The code for generating `TableIdentifier`s for every table is very different than the filtered solution - we might want to keep the code separated (different method, or a clearly different code path inside of a single method). Also we can decide that we do not want to support this feature, but that is a different discussion/PR etc.
2. If we see that there are code duplications (HiveTableOperations/HiveViewOperations) then I prefer one of the following 2 methods:
    - Do the refactor in a 1st PR, to extract the code which will be reused, and in a 2nd PR add the new feature. It is fine to do the WIP PR to decide which will be the common parts, but we should not commit code which is not production ready.
    - Do the refactor and the new feature in the same PR. It is viable only for small refactors.
3. We should decide if we want to have the same error messages for the `HiveCatalog` that are used by the other Catalogs. If we think so, then it would be great if the new error messages (for the Views) should be the same.
@innocent123: I do not really understand your question, but I think your problem might be similar to #5846.

@dragon-feng: Could you please check which execution engine you are using?

My guess is, that you are using `set hive.execution.engine=tez`. And it is working for reads, but not supported for writes. The execution of the insert is finished, but the data files are not added to the Iceberg table.

I would suggest to try out Hive 4.0.0, as it has out-of-the-box support for Iceberg tables.

You can find the supported features / engines here: https://iceberg.apache.org/docs/latest/hive/

> 
> Iceberg compatibility with Hive 2.x and Hive 3.1.2/3 supports the following features:
> 
> - Creating a table
> - Dropping a table
> - Reading a table
> - Inserting into a table (INSERT INTO)
>
> DML operations work only with MapReduce execution engine.
@manuzhang does that also fix https://github.com/apache/iceberg/issues/8949 or is that a different root cause?
@nastra #8949 is a different RC.

@leewjae do you have a specific use case for using this? Most of the time `StaticTableOperations` will be used in cases where only the location is serialized and available and not the full `TableMetadata`, such as in `SerializableTable`. 
The only other place where this could be used is potentially `BaseSparkAction`.
I'm starting to review. Thanks !
@jacobmarble can you break this into smaller commits? There are a ton of files changed here and I'm concerned about catching problems with such a large PR.
Thanks @jerqi and @boushphong for the review

body: @pvary :In contrast, the tez engine I use supports writing, but not reading.

@pvary However, writing data does have problems. The data directory is generated normally, and the data file is also generated normally, but the metadata directory only has the matedata.json file and version-tint.text file

> primary key in flink is identifier fields in iceberg

@Zhangg7723 Can you show me a simple example of creating a primary key table? Thank you.
@RussellSpitzer @boushphong Thanks for your review.
Quick check on any progress or plan/timeline for this request?

Hey guys, I have some questions about the API change here.

1. Do we need to differentiate the case when default value is not specified, and the case when default value is explicitly set to null? I guess it won't be necessary for optional columns, but not sure about required columns.
2. NestedField is a `Serializable`. So I think we need to make sure the default value objects, e.g. `StructLike`, are also serializables right?

> @leewjae do you have a specific use case for using this? Most of the time StaticTableOperations will be used in cases where only the location is serialized and available and not the full TableMetadata, such as in SerializableTable.
The only other place where this could be used is potentially BaseSparkAction.

We are using `StaticTableOperations` to build a read only table from the cache (which has table metadata cached). Hence, we don't want to do an extra IO again.

> This leaves us again with the question of what to use for the storage table pointer.

I think table UUID or location is fine. Same should apply when referencing the base tables and their respective snapshot IDs. Maybe for base tables, UUID makes more sense.

I agree with @rdblue 

For partition stat we had a PR dedicated for spec. 
As it's not necessary the same reviewers, I think it's good to have one PR for spec (even if it's very small) and PRs for api and impl.
@pvary please have a look, thanks
after 1.4.2, no IllegalArgumentException

Thanks for your input. The discussion has moved to the Google doc (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UnhldHhe3Grz8JBngwXPA6ZZord1xMedY5ukEhZYF-A/edit?usp=sharing). It would be great if you could add your comment there. Then it will have a higher visibility.
@leewjae can you please adjust `BaseSparkAction` to use the new constructor? After that the PR should be good to go
@nastra done
I would be happy to take this if there is no objection.
`RESTMessage` is an interface that does not carry any contents. Are there any particular messages that you would like to compare?

> `RESTMessage` is an interface that does not carry any contents. Are there any particular messages that you would like to compare?

Oh, sorry, I mean all the concrete implementations, such as `ConfigResponse`.
@liurenjie1024 No problem and I think that makes sense to be able to check those for equality.
Cool, I will take this.
cc @Fokko Please help to assign it to me.
may be you can add  .config("spark.sql.extensions", "org.apache.iceberg.spark.extensions.IcebergSparkSessionExtensions") and try again

@pvary , My Bad i didn't understand the initial commends on loading all the table data from HMS. As you mentioned initial implementation was not filtering to construct the `tableIdentifiers` for `listAllTables`. I have addressed these comments. Also followed the same strategy of `InMemoryCatalog` in terms of Error for Hive Catalog. 
Regarding the code duplications (`HiveTableOperations`/`HiveViewOperations`) I am creating another PR that can go before this.

> @pvary However, writing data does have problems. The data directory is generated normally, and the data file is also generated normally, but the metadata directory only has the matedata.json file and version-tint.text file

So if I understand correctly this confirms, that the issues is with the write, and not the read.
Am I right?

I have 2 PRs in progress, which I would like to merge first (#8803 and #8553). If nobody starts working on this until they are merged, then I will move forward with this one. I plan to use the original method of upgrading (independent path for every Flink version). I would like to see the 1.18 available before the end of the year - but hopefully sooner

Thanks @lirui-apache!
Merged
Thanks @pvary !

Still reproducible on 1.4.2.
Can I take this one? :bow:  @nastra

actually I don't think this is a bug
This would produce DDL like Spark-SQL API.
```scala
df.write.partitionBy("vendor_id").saveAsTable("local.nyc.taxis_df")
```

When adding
```
--conf spark.sql.extensions=org.apache.iceberg.spark.extensions.IcebergSparkSessionExtensions \
```
in addition to the set of configs listed above, I can't even start `spark-sql`:
```
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/spark/sql/catalyst/expressions/AnsiCast
	at org.apache.iceberg.spark.extensions.IcebergSparkSessionExtensions.$anonfun$apply$6(IcebergSparkSessionExtensions.scala:54)
```

Without it, at least I can query tables and get results. With it, I get the exception above on startup.

> @jacobmarble can you break this into smaller commits? There are a ton of files changed here and I'm concerned about catching problems with such a large PR.

> I agree with @rdblue
> 
> For partition stat we had a PR dedicated for spec. As it's not necessary the same reviewers, I think it's good to have one PR for spec (even if it's very small) and PRs for api and impl.

Happy to split this up. I tried to scope this to API and Core, but the cascade of failing tests led to this.

Do these need to be addressed in this PR?

body: check dependence spark-extensions module correctly
Any more comments?

> @innocent123: I do not really understand your question, but I think your problem might be similar to #5846.

when i use spark api rewriteDataFiles is reported "org.apache.iceberg.exceptions.RuntimeIOException:  Failed to get block locations for path: hdfs://xxxx/iceberg-hive/hadoop_prod/iceberg_x5l_pre/xxx/data/sample_date=20231107/00009-0-54295f94-ef26-44be-b6b8-ca3e472d9482-00010.parquet"

How do I fix this error?

> 
> when i use spark api rewriteDataFiles is reported "org.apache.iceberg.exceptions.RuntimeIOException: Failed to get block locations for path: hdfs://xxxx/iceberg-hive/hadoop_prod/iceberg_x5l_pre/xxx/data/sample_date=20231107/00009-0-54295f94-ef26-44be-b6b8-ca3e472d9482-00010.parquet"

this data file is lose,and manifest_path still exist
spark version 3.0.2
iceberg version1.0.0
I think it would be good to also get the opinion of @RussellSpitzer or @aokolnychyi on this one
@boushphong yes feel free to work on this in case you're interested

Delta Lake has the ability to set  `spark.databricks.delta.schema.autoMerge.enabled`. I find this approach interesting as it can be used only when required.  Once set the automatic schema evolution works for every write operation.
@dependabot rebase
Upgrading to 1.4.1 or later **AND** rewriting manifests seems to resolve this.
@melin thanks for opening the issue, however it's not really clear what you're asking for and what problem you're facing. Could you please re-phrase your question so that we can better help?

User drops table, data is not deleted and occupies storage space. It is not very convenient to delete files from s3 separately. If catalog supports add parameter, set managed or EXTERNAL. Selected by the user. More flexible
 
Recreate the table with the same name. The data directory already exists. Also, the execution fails
The test failures are because the backend catalog in `TestRESTCatalog` doesn't support views, hence I switched it to `InMemoryCatalog` in https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/9014
thanks for the reviews @bryanck and @Fokko
Does it mean the spec will be published prior to a release?
I am also interested in this functionality as well! Are there still plans to add this?

Hey @aokolnychyi This PR means that the [`mkdocs` dependencies](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/main/site/requirements.txt) will be kept up to date.

@bitsondatadev is working in https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/8919 to add the site as part of this repository. There will be a `nightly`/`latest`/`dev` build as well that would publish the spec before a release.
cc @RussellSpitzer

> @deniskuzZ: Is there there something like this ongoing in the Hive codebase?

hi @pvary, we have iceberg MV backed by iceberg table support in Hive where query definitions are stored in HMS and data in Iceberg table: HIVE-26578, HIVE-27101
Currently investigating how we could compute the delta between snapshots for incremental MV rebuild.
